awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Data-Driven Retention in Crowdsourced Image Analysis and Mapping
awd_abstract_narration:
This research aims to improve individual participation, retention, and repeat engagement in citizen science image analysis. Improving engagement in citizen science may accelerate the pace of problem solving and discovery by allowing contributions from a larger group of people, broaden participation, and allow new pathways for involvement for communities who may not otherwise have had them.  This project seeks to serve and build smaller regional non-profit organizations that are vital to regional resilience by connecting participants with organizations proposing projects and encouraging participant re-engagement and collaboration.  It will develop and deploy an open-source web platform and toolkit for creating engaging citizen science projects.  The motivating application is disaster response, which has the potential for broader impact as disasters are increasing in frequency and severity. However, the general approaches can be applied more broadly in the citizen science, crowdsourcing, human computation, and human-computer-interaction communities.

This project has three main research aims.  First, it will develop techniques to automatically improve the onboarding process of online citizen science projects. This will help to understand the impact of early tasks on longer-term engagement in such projects.  Second, it aims to develop a model of participant disengagement that can be used to guide interventions that dynamically adjust to individual participants. These interventions will be examined in the context of multiple tasks types, limited participant history, and relevant diversions within the workflow.  Third, while most crowdsourced citizen science projects are driven by formal academic researchers and large-scale organizations, a goal of this project is to build a research platform where small to medium scale community based organizations can set the research agenda and explore the different questions and aims they pursue.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Cartoscope is an open source image categorization platform developed for public interest non-profits to organize crowdsourcing citizen science projects. 

 

Working with two non-profit organizations — Healthy Gulf in Louisiana and Unique Mappers from Port Harcourt Nigeria — we developed a series of successful citizen science projects looking at loss of, and damage to, wetlands. With Healthy Gulf we developed Land Loss Lookout, which analyzed the loss of wetlands in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana from Climate Change and oil and gas extraction. We published a peer reviewed paper on the project and engaged over 2,000 volunteers in analyzing wetland loss. The project was featured on National Public Radio’s Science Friday and MSNBC’s Peacock nightly news in 2021. 

 

Working with Healthy Gulf we also developed rapid crowdsourced identification of oil spills and industrially related damage from Hurricane Ida called Ida Damage Lookout. The project categorized 102 oil spills following Hurricane Ida.

 

One of the largest contributors to Land Loss Lookout was Unique Mappers, a Nigerian Citizen Science organization. Following Land Loss Lookout, Unique Mappers reached out to build a citizen science project in their delta to identify damage from oil spills. In 2022 we collaboratively developed Land Pollution Lookout which engaged hundreds of participants from Nigeria and the US in a one week sprint to look for oil spill damage in protected wetland areas of the Niger Delta. The project identified damage from 98 oil spills. 

 

For all of our projects we collaborated with the non-profit organization SciStarter to share and publicize our project.

 

Cartoscope is also a platform for experimentally analyzing crowd engagement and participation. As a research site our platform has so far published five peer-reviewed computer science publications exploring aspects such as how to improve participants retention, engagement and enjoyment. We have developed algorithmic machine learning approaches to adjusting task ordering based on prior performance, and we are developing ways to train machine learning models based on crowd-data. We developed a prototype augmented reality toolkit that allows images to be categorized by playing a variety of games that incorporate both physical and digital components. We have also been able to explore the performance of both volunteer participants and those who contribute via paid crowdsourcing.


Last Modified: 01/09/2023
Modified by: Seth Cooper

Cartoscope is an open source image categorization platform developed for public interest non-profits to organize crowdsourcing citizen science projects. 

 
Working with two non-profit organizations — Healthy Gulf in Louisiana and Unique Mappers from Port Harcourt Nigeria — we developed a series of successful citizen science projects looking at loss of, and damage to, wetlands. With Healthy Gulf we developed Land Loss Lookout, which analyzed the loss of wetlands in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana from Climate Change and oil and gas extraction. Working with Healthy Gulf we also developed rapid crowdsourced identification of oil spills and industrially related damage from Hurricane Ida called Ida Damage Lookout. The project categorized 102 oil spills following Hurricane Ida.

 
One of the largest contributors to Land Loss Lookout was Unique Mappers, a Nigerian Citizen Science organization. In 2022 we collaboratively developed Land Pollution Lookout which engaged hundreds of participants from Nigeria and the US in a one week sprint to look for oil spill damage in protected wetland areas of the Niger Delta.
